dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, I just read this and I'm like... mind blown.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, I just read this and I'm like... mind blown.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Because, like, companies, big ones, like Lowe's, Taco Bell, they're actually paying for their employees to get degrees?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Because, like, companies, big ones, like Lowe's, Taco Bell, they're actually paying for their employees to get degrees?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! High school, college, all of it! It's like, uh, Guild Education, you know? They help them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! High school, college, all of it! It's like, uh, Guild Education, you know? They help them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the co-founder, Rachel Carlson, she said it just makes them more attractive to work for. Higher retention, better recruitment...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the co-founder, Rachel Carlson, she said it just makes them more attractive to work for. Higher retention, better recruitment...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh totally! More upskilling, like, better brand! Who wouldn't want that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh totally! More upskilling, like, better brand! Who wouldn't want that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But here's the wild part, it's not just white-collar folks. We're talking like, 64 million frontline workers! Cashiers, customer service, wait staff...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But here's the wild part, it's not just white-collar folks. We're talking like, sixty four million frontline workers! Cashiers, customer service, wait staff...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world. This group includes cashiers, customer service representatives, restaurant wait staff and cooks, and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, prisoners! Did you see that? They have a government contract to educate prisoners!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, prisoners! Did you see that? They have a government contract to educate prisoners!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! Right? Like, oh my gosh! Walmart, for example, their Live Better U program? Employees pay a dollar a day for tuition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! Right? Like, oh my gosh! Walmart, for example, their Live Better U program? Employees pay a dollar a day for tuition.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, a dollar a day? And the company pays, what, a thousand? That's insane!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, a dollar a day? And the company pays, what, a thousand? That's insane!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And Stephanie Ruhle, like, she said analysts always ask about the bad stuff, but this? This is good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And Stephanie Ruhle, like, she said analysts always ask about the bad stuff, but this? This is good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's not a pat on the back thing, it's about profits, like, it helps their recruitment and retention, instead of destroying it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not a pat on the back thing, it's about profits, like, it helps their recruitment and retention, instead of destroying it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, CEOs apparently hated sending people back to school because it destroyed their numbers before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, CEOs apparently hated sending people back to school because it destroyed their numbers before.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It makes sense, you know? And they've gotten, what, like $70 billion in funding? Wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It makes sense, you know? And they've gotten, what, like seventy dollars billion in funding? Wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right?! But then, uh, the gig economy thing? Like, Lyft drivers now have to pay full tuition because of a revised tax code?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right?! But then, uh, the gig economy thing? Like, Lyft drivers now have to pay full tuition because of a revised tax code?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might. That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And it says, "This change is the company's greatest win to date." What?! For Lyft? Or for Guild? I'm like, confused there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And it says, This change is the company's greatest win to date. What?! For Lyft? Or for Guild? I'm like, confused there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a bit like, hmm, who's winning there, exactly? But overall, this is a huge shift.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, a massive shift! Like, investing in your people, even if they're frontline. It's just smart business.
